originalTitle: Zimbabwe rejects 'lopsided' US health aid deal over data concerns
title: Zimbabwe Says 'No' to a Tricky Health Deal!
content:
Hello from your African News Reporter!

Hello, wonderful friends across Africa! It’s me, your kid-friendly news reporter, here to share a story from our amazing continent. Today, we are going to talk about something important that happened in a country called Zimbabwe. It’s a place with beautiful wildlife and warm people, just like many of our homes. We talk about health and how countries work together. It’s like when you play with your friends, and everyone wants to be fair.

What Happened in Zimbabwe?

Imagine someone offered you a yummy snack, but they said, "I'll give you this snack, but I get to eat all the special sprinkles on top, and you don't get any." That wouldn't feel very fair, would it? Well, something a bit like that happened in Zimbabwe. A big country far away, called the United States (or the US for short), wanted to help Zimbabwe with health. They offered a health deal. But Zimbabwe looked at the deal and said, "Hmm, this doesn't feel quite right. It's not fair." So, they said "no." It’s good to stand up for what is fair, don’t you think?

What is "Health Aid"?

"Health aid" is when one country helps another country with things like medicine, doctors, or hospitals. It's like when your mom helps you put a bandage on a scraped knee. It's help to keep people healthy and safe. The US wanted to give Zimbabwe help for health. This is usually a very good thing! It helps people get better when they are sick and prevents them from getting sick in the first place. Many countries help each other with health aid. It shows we care about everyone. *Did you know?* Doctors and nurses work very hard to keep us all healthy. They are like superheroes in scrubs!

What are "Biological Samples"?

Now, this is a bit of a grown-up word, but let's make it simple. "Biological samples" are tiny bits from our bodies that doctors and scientists can look at. Think of it like this: If you cut your finger, a tiny drop of blood comes out, right? Or when you go to the doctor, they might ask you to spit in a little cup. Those tiny drops of blood or spit are "biological samples." Scientists look at these samples under a powerful microscope. They want to learn how our bodies work and why we get sick. This helps them find new medicines to make us feel better. *Did you know?* Your body is made up of billions of tiny building blocks called cells! Each cell is so small you can't see it without a microscope.

Why Was Zimbabwe Worried?

Zimbabwe said "no" because of these samples. The US wanted to take these tiny bits from people in Zimbabwe. This is for research, to learn more about sickness. That part is okay. But here’s the tricky bit: The US did not want to share what they learned. They didn't want to share the good things that came from studying Zimbabwe's samples. It’s like if you shared your special toy with a friend to help them play. But then your friend learns a cool new trick with your toy, and they say, "I'm not going to show you this cool trick, it's just for me!" Zimbabwe felt that this was not fair. They wanted to share in the "benefits" of the research. "Benefits" means all the good new things learned. They wanted to know about any new medicines or discoveries that came from their people's samples. They wanted to make sure their people could also use these new things.

What Does "Research" Mean?

"Research" is like being a detective! Scientists are detectives who look for clues. They want to solve puzzles about sickness and health. They study samples, read books, and do experiments to find answers. Their goal is to find new ways to help people live longer and healthier lives. For example, research helps us find new vaccines to stop us from getting sick from viruses, like the flu. It helps us understand why some people get certain diseases. *Did you know?* Scientists work all over the world, trying to find cures for diseases. They are like a big team, even if they are far apart!

Why is Sharing Important?

Zimbabwe believes that if they give their samples for research, they should also get to share in the good things that come from that research. It’s about being a team! Imagine you and a friend are baking a cake together. You bring the eggs, and your friend brings the flour. You both work together to make a delicious cake. Would it be fair if only one of you got to eat the cake? No! You would both share it. Zimbabwe wants to be sure that if their people help with important health research, their people also get to use any new medicines or treatments that come from it. It’s about teamwork and being fair to everyone. It’s important that countries work together as partners. This means everyone is treated with respect and kindness.

What Happens Now?

So, Zimbabwe said "no" to this specific deal. They want a deal that is more fair. They want a deal where everyone shares the good things. This doesn't mean Zimbabwe doesn't want help. They do! But they want help that feels fair for their people. Sometimes, when two friends have a disagreement, they talk about it again. They try to find a way that makes both happy. We hope that Zimbabwe and the US can talk more and find a fair way to work together. This way, everyone can be healthier and happier! *Did you know?* Zimbabwe is famous for its incredible Victoria Falls, one of the largest waterfalls in the world!

Let's Learn Together!

This story teaches us that it’s very important to be fair. It teaches us that when people work together, they should share the good results. Always remember to be fair with your friends and family. And let’s all wish for good health and happiness for everyone in Zimbabwe and all over Africa! Thank you for listening, little news reporters!
summary: Zimbabwe said "no" to a health help deal from the US because they wanted a fair share of new health discoveries made from tiny samples from their people.
whyMatters: This is important because countries should work together fairly to make sure everyone gets healthy and shares in good new discoveries, just like sharing toys with friends.

originalTitle: Pope Leo to visit four African countries in April
title: A Very Special Visitor is Coming to Africa!
content:
Hello, Friends! Guess Who's Coming?

Hey, super kids of Africa! We have some really exciting news today! Imagine a very, very important person who travels all around the world, sharing smiles and good messages. Well, guess what? That special person is coming to *our* amazing continent, Africa! His name is Pope Leo. He is like a very kind and wise grandpa to millions and millions of people all over the world. He talks about love, peace, and being good to everyone. Isn't that wonderful? He is excited to see Africa and meet many new friends.

Who is Pope Leo?

Pope Leo is a very special leader. He is the leader of a big church family called the Catholic Church. Many, many people around the world are part of this family. The Pope lives in a special place far away called Vatican City, which is in a country called Italy. He wears special white clothes and sometimes a special hat! He is known for being kind and for helping people understand how to live together with love. He loves children very much and always has a warm smile for everyone. He travels to different countries to tell people about peace and kindness. He wants everyone to be friends. *Did you know?* The Pope has a special car called the "Popemobile"! It's like a big, clear car so everyone can see him and wave hello when he drives by! It keeps him safe too. How cool is that?

Pope Leo's Big Trip to Africa

Our friend Pope Leo is getting ready for a big adventure! He is going to visit *four* different countries right here in Africa. Wow! That’s a lot of flying and meeting new people. He will be visiting us very soon, in April. April is a month when the weather starts to change in some places, and flowers begin to bloom! He is coming to share happy messages and to listen to the people of Africa. He wants to know what life is like here. He wants to share his message of hope and joy. It is a very big trip for him, and we are all so excited he chose to visit our home.

Why is He Visiting Africa?

Pope Leo loves to visit different places to meet people. He wants to talk about very important things like peace, love, and helping each other. He wants to see the beautiful lands and friendly faces of Africa. He will meet children just like you! He will also meet important leaders to talk about making our world a better place for everyone. He believes that every person is special and deserves love and happiness. He wants to make sure people are kind to each other and live without fighting. That is his very important job. He cares a lot about our planet and all the people living on it. *Simple Explanation:* What is "peace"? Peace means everyone is happy and calm. It means no fighting, no shouting, and lots of smiles. When people have peace, they can play together, learn together, and help each other grow. Pope Leo wants peace for everyone.

A Special Stop in Algeria

Now, here is something extra special about Pope Leo’s trip! One of the four countries he will visit is a place called Algeria. Algeria is a very big country in North Africa. It has sunny deserts and beautiful mountains. But what makes this visit super special is that it's the *very first time* a Pope will visit Algeria! Can you imagine? It's a truly historic moment. Many people in Algeria are Muslim. This means they follow a religion called Islam. This is different from the Christian religion that Pope Leo leads. *Did you know?* Algeria is the largest country in Africa! It has huge deserts, called the Sahara Desert, where you might see camels! Imagine seeing Pope Leo near a camel!

Friends from Different Religions

In Algeria, most people are Muslim. They go to a special building called a mosque to pray. Pope Leo is a Christian leader, and Christians go to a church to pray. Even though they pray in different ways and have different traditions, they both believe in being good, kind, and loving to others. Pope Leo visiting Algeria is like two big families from different neighborhoods coming together to share a meal and become friends. It shows that people from different religions can be friends and respect each other. They can learn from each other and share happiness. *Simple Explanation:* What is a "religion"? A religion is a special way that people believe in God or important ideas. It helps them understand the world and how to live. There are many different religions in the world, like Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, and Buddhism. They all teach us to be good people.

What Will Pope Leo Do There?

During his visit to these countries, Pope Leo will do many things. He will meet with important leaders of the countries to talk about how to help people and make things better. He will meet with children and families to share his blessings and hear their stories. He will talk about how important it is for everyone to live together in peace, no matter where they come from or how they pray. He wants everyone to be kind to each other. He might give special talks, called speeches, where he shares his ideas about love and friendship. He hopes to bring smiles and hope to everyone he meets. *Did you know?* When Pope Leo gives a special blessing, it's like sending out good wishes and prayers to people. Many people feel happy and hopeful after receiving his blessing.

A Message of Hope and Togetherness

Pope Leo's visit to Africa is a very big deal! It is a sign of hope and friendship. It shows that people from all over the world can come together, even if they have different ideas or come from different places. He wants to teach us that love is the strongest thing in the world. When he visits Algeria, it's a special way of showing that Christians and Muslims can be good friends and work together for a better world. Let's send Pope Leo a big African welcome and wish him a wonderful and safe trip! We hope his visit brings lots of happiness and peace to everyone! Hooray for Pope Leo!
summary: Pope Leo, a very important world leader, is visiting four countries in Africa, including Algeria for the first time, to share messages of peace and friendship with everyone.
whyMatters: This visit is important because Pope Leo wants to help people from different places and religions be kind to each other and live happily together, making our world more peaceful.

originalTitle: UN sanctions paramilitary leaders over Sudan atrocities
title: Helping Sudan Find Peace: The World Says NO to Bad Actions!
content:
Hello from Africa!

Hi everyone! It's your kid-friendly news reporter here, bringing you some important news from our wonderful continent, Africa. Today, we're going to talk about a country called Sudan. Sudan is a very big and beautiful country, right here in Africa! Sometimes, grown-ups have big problems, and that's what happened in Sudan. But guess what? Other grown-ups, from all around the world, are trying to help make things better. It’s like when you see a friend sad, and you want to help them smile again. That's what's happening now in a big way for Sudan.

What's Happening in Sudan?

For a little while, there has been some fighting in Sudan. When people fight, it’s really sad. Homes can get broken, and children can't always go to school or play outside safely. Imagine if your playground wasn't safe anymore – it would make you feel very sad, right? This fighting has made many people in Sudan feel sad and scared. It's not a game; it's a serious problem that makes life very hard for regular families. They just want to live peacefully and happily, like all of us. **Did you know?** Sudan is one of the largest countries in Africa! It has amazing rivers like the Nile and beautiful deserts. It's a place with a rich history and many different kinds of people.

A City Called Nyala

There's a city in Sudan called Nyala. Last year, something very, very sad happened there. Some groups of people were fighting very badly in Nyala. It was one of the hardest times for the people living in that city. When there's fighting, people sometimes have to leave their homes quickly to find a safe place. This is called becoming a 'refugee' or 'displaced person'. They have to leave their toys, their clothes, and sometimes even their pets behind. It’s a very difficult thing to go through, and it happened to many families in Nyala because of the fighting there. This kind of fighting is called 'atrocities' because it means very cruel and harmful things happened to innocent people. Nobody should ever have to go through something like that. Everyone deserves to be safe and protected in their own homes and communities. When bad things like this happen, it's important for the world to notice and try to stop it from happening again. That’s why the big grown-ups from around the world got together to talk about Sudan and Nyala. **Did you know?** The capital city of Sudan is Khartoum. It's where the two main parts of the River Nile meet! It's a very important city for the country.

Who Are These Leaders?

In Sudan, there are some groups of people who have been fighting. The leaders of these groups are like the people who tell others what to do in their team. But some of these leaders told their groups to do bad things. They made the fighting worse, and they hurt many people. These specific leaders are from a group called the 'RSF'. They are grown-ups who caused a lot of trouble and made life very dangerous for many families in Sudan. It's not fair when leaders cause so much sadness and pain, especially to innocent children and families who just want peace. They are responsible for many of the sad things that happened, like in Nyala. When you do something wrong, like pushing someone or taking their toy, your parents or teachers might give you a 'time-out', right? Well, the world has a way of giving grown-ups a 'time-out' too, especially when they do very, very bad things that hurt many people. This is to show them that their actions are not okay and must stop. It's also to help protect the people who are being harmed.

What is a "Sanction"? (A Special Time-Out)

So, what is this "time-out" called for grown-ups? It's called a 'sanction'. The United Nations, which is like a very, very big club where almost all the countries in the world are members, decided to put sanctions on some of these leaders in Sudan. What does a sanction mean? It means these leaders can't travel to other countries anymore. It also means they can't use their money that they might have gotten from doing bad things. It's like taking away their special privileges because they didn't follow the rules of being a good world citizen. Imagine if you couldn't go to your friend's house or buy your favorite sweets because you were naughty. That's a bit like what a sanction is for these leaders. These sanctions are a way for the world to say, "We see what you're doing, and it's not okay!" It's a serious punishment to try and make them stop the fighting and help bring peace back to Sudan. The goal is not just to punish, but to change their behavior and protect innocent people. The world wants these leaders to understand that peace is much better than fighting, and that everyone deserves to live in a safe place without fear. **Did you know?** The United Nations (UN) was started a long time ago, after a very big war, to help countries work together for peace and safety. Almost every country in the world is a member! Their symbol is a globe surrounded by olive branches, which stand for peace.

Why the World Helps (The Big UN Club)

Why does the United Nations do this? Because the UN's biggest job is to help keep peace all over the world. They want every child, every family, and every country to be safe and happy. When one country has a big problem like fighting, the UN tries to step in and help. They send people to talk, they send food and medicine to help those who are hurt or have no homes, and sometimes, like now, they give 'sanctions' to leaders who are causing trouble. They want to make sure everyone's 'human rights' are protected. Human rights mean that everyone has the right to live safely, go to school, eat good food, and be treated kindly. This action by the UN is like a group of friends telling a bully to stop. They are standing up for the people of Sudan, especially the children who have suffered so much. It shows that the world cares and that bad actions have consequences. The hope is that these punishments will make the fighting stop and encourage everyone to work together to rebuild Sudan and make it a peaceful place for everyone to live and play again. It's a big step towards making things right.

Hoping for Peace

Even though there has been sadness and fighting in Sudan, there is always hope for peace. When leaders stop fighting and choose to talk instead, amazing things can happen. Children can go back to school, families can go back to their homes, and everyone can play safely again. The world, through the United Nations, is trying its best to help Sudan find this peace. They are trying to make sure that the people who caused harm understand that it was wrong and that they need to stop. This news about the 'sanctions' is a sign that the world is paying attention and wants to help. It shows that leaders who cause harm will face consequences. Let's all hope and send our good wishes that Sudan will soon be a very peaceful and happy place for all its wonderful people. We want to see children laughing and playing freely across the whole country. Peace is the best thing for everyone! **Did you know?** Many people in Sudan love to drink strong coffee and sweet tea! They are also famous for their delicious food, like 'aseeda', which is a type of porridge.

Let's Learn More About Africa!

Sudan is just one of many amazing countries in Africa. Africa is a continent full of diverse cultures, beautiful animals like lions and elephants, and incredible natural wonders. Learning about different countries, even when they face challenges, helps us understand the world better. We can all hope for a future where peace and happiness spread across every part of our beloved continent. Keep watching this space for more kid-friendly news about Africa and beyond!

originalTitle: Cuban border agents fire upon Florida-tagged speedboat, killing four
title: A Story About Boats, Borders, and Rules
content:
Hello, my wonderful friends! Today, we have a story from a country called Cuba. Cuba is an island, which means it's a big piece of land surrounded by lots and lots of water. Imagine your home. Around your home, there's a garden or a yard. That garden is like a country's special water. Just like your home has rules about who can come in, countries have rules too. Especially about who can come into their water. This story is a little bit sad, but it teaches us very important things about rules and safety. Let's learn together.

What are Borders?

Every country has invisible lines around it. We call these lines 'borders.' Borders are like magical fences that you can't see, but they are very important. They show us where one country ends and another country begins. Some borders are on land, like the line between two countries that touch each other. Other borders are in the big ocean, around islands or countries that are next to the sea. Did you know? Africa has many countries, and each one has its own borders too! These borders help each country stay special and keep its people safe.

Who are Border Agents?

Countries have special helpers called 'border agents.' Their job is like being a helpful guard for the country's borders. They watch to make sure everyone who comes in or goes out follows the rules. They are there to keep everyone safe, just like your teachers keep you safe at school, or your parents keep you safe at home. Border agents make sure things are peaceful and orderly. Did you know? Border agents also check for things that aren't allowed into a country, like certain types of food or toys, to help keep everyone healthy and happy in their country!

What is a Speedboat?

Now, let's talk about boats! There are many kinds of boats in the world. Some are big ships that carry many people, and some are small boats for fishing. A speedboat is a special kind of boat. It has a very powerful engine that makes it zoom across the water super quickly. People use speedboats for fun, or sometimes to travel fast from one place to another. Did you know? The fastest speedboats can go as fast as a car on a road! Imagine how quickly they can cross the water!

What Happened with the Speedboat?

One day, a very fast speedboat was out on the water. This speedboat went into the water that belongs to Cuba. It went into Cuba's 'garden' without asking for permission first. This is like someone walking into your house without knocking on the door or being invited. When the border agents saw the speedboat, they knew it wasn't following the rules. The border agents tried to tell the speedboat to stop. They wanted to understand why it was there. But the speedboat did not stop. It kept going fast. When people don't follow important rules, especially about borders, sometimes very sad things can happen. In this story, because the speedboat did not stop and followed its own path, there was a very, very sad accident. Some people on the speedboat sadly lost their lives. It's a very sad thing when people get hurt or lose their lives. That's why rules are so important. They are there to help everyone stay safe and avoid sad accidents like this. Did you know? It's always best to ask for permission before you go into someone else's space, whether it's a friend's house, a game, or another country's water!

Why Do Countries Have Rules for Their Water?

Countries have rules for their water for many good reasons. One big reason is to keep everyone safe. If anyone could just zoom into a country's water without asking, bad things could happen. Another reason is to protect special fish or plants that live in the water. Countries want to make sure their natural treasures are safe and sound. They want to protect the animals and plants in their 'water garden.' Also, countries want to know who is coming and going. This helps them manage their country better, just like your parents know who is coming to visit your home. It's all about safety and order. Did you know? Many countries in Africa have beautiful coastlines and lots of water. They also have rules to protect their oceans, rivers, and the amazing animals that live there, like colourful fish and even big whales!

Learning from This Story

This sad story teaches us something very important. It teaches us that rules are there for a good reason. Rules help us to live together safely and happily. When everyone follows the rules, we can avoid misunderstandings and sad accidents. It also teaches us that if we need to go to another country, or even just cross an invisible line, it's always best to do it the right way. We should ask for permission and follow what the border agents say. They are doing their job to keep everyone safe. Did you know? When you travel with your family, you often have to show a special book called a 'passport' to cross borders. This passport tells border agents who you are and where you are from, so they know you are following the rules!

Thinking About Peace

Even though this was a sad story, it reminds us to think about peace. Peace means everyone getting along and being kind to each other. Countries also try to live in peace with their neighbours. When everyone respects each other's 'invisible fences' and follows the rules, we can have a more peaceful world. It's like playing a game with your friends. If everyone follows the rules of the game, it's fair and fun for everyone. If someone doesn't follow the rules, it can make others sad or even cause problems. So, let's always try to follow rules and be kind, whether we are playing in our yard or thinking about big countries in the world. Did you know? There is a special day every year called 'International Day of Peace'! On this day, people all over the world think about how to make our planet more peaceful and friendly for everyone.
summary: A speedboat went into Cuba's waters without permission, and when it did not stop for border agents, a very sad accident happened where some people lost their lives, showing why rules and borders are important for safety.
whyMatters: This story matters because it teaches us that rules are very important for countries, just like they are important for us, to keep everyone safe and avoid sad problems, and that we should always respect borders and follow directions.

title: Why do we miss 2016?
content: First of a series exploring the defining moments of the past decade.

originalTitle: Russia considers fuel support for Cuba as Canada pledges food aid
title: Russia considers fuel support for Cuba as Canada pledges food aid
content: A US-imposed fuel embargo has threatened to spark a humanitarian crisis in Cuba, whose energy grid relies on fossil fuel

content: Culiacán in northern Mexico has seen a surge in violence as rival factions of the Sinaloa cartel battle for control.

content: The next round of talks between the US and Iran in Geneva on Thursday could be decisive in the president's decision-making.

content: A newspaper reports Gates apologised to staff over his links to Epstein and said: "I did nothing illicit. I saw nothing illicit."

content: The amount Manchester United owe increases to almost £1.3bn in outstanding transfer fees, rolling credit facility and legacy debt.

originalTitle: Uefa rejects Benfica appeal over Prestianni ban
title: Uefa rejects Benfica appeal over Prestianni ban
content: Gianluca Prestianni will miss the second leg of Benfica's Champions League tie against Real Madrid after Uefa reject the club's appeal against his suspension.

title: Terry 'frustrated' over Chelsea caretaker choice
content: Former Chelsea captain John Terry says he is "frustrated" at being overlooked for a caretaker role following Enzo Maresca's departure as head coach in January.
